sn46.5:4.2: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha …
sn46.5:4.5: How are the awakening factors defined?”
sn46.5:4.6: “Mendicant, they’re called awakening factors because they lead to awakening.
sn46.5:4.7: A mendicant develops the awakening-factors of mindfulness, investigation of principles, energy, rapture, tranquility, samādhi, and
sn46.5:4.8: equanimity, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.
sn46.5:4.9: As they develop the seven awakening factors, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire for rebirth, and ignorance.
sn46.5:4.10: When freed, they know ‘it is freed’.
sn46.5:4.11: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’
sn46.5:4.12: They’re called awakening factors because they lead to awakening.”
